deck: Creator of the Goon.
description:
Career

Powell has written and provided artwork for franchises of Dark Horse Comics, DC Comics and Marvel but is most regarded for his original series The Goon, which debuted from the small publisher Avatar Press. Powell quickly switched to self-publishing under the moniker Exploding Albatross Funnybooks before being picked up by Dark Horse after only a handful of issues. The Goon's quality was recognized with an Eisner Award in 2004 for Best Single Issue (Dark Horse The Goon #1) as well as an International Horror Guild award. The following year Powell won Eisner's Best Humor Publication and Best Continuing Series awards.

He is a featured interviewee in the movie Independents. Additionally, he has illustrated roller derby bout posters for Fracture Magazine.

Powell will co-write the first two volumes of IDW Publishing 's Godzilla: Kingdom of Monsters with Tracy Marsh.

Awards

  • Winner 2004 Eisner Award Best Single Issue for The Goon #1
  • Winner 2004 International Horror Guild Best Illustrated Narrative for The Goon #1-4
  • Winner 2005 Eisner Award Best Humor Publication for The Goon
  • Winner 2005 Eisner Award Best Continuing Series for The Goon
  • Winner 2008 Einser Award Best Writer/Artist Humor for The Goon
  • Winner 2008 Eisner Award Best Painter or Multimedia Artist-Interior for The Goon: Chinatown and the Mystery of Mr. Wicker
name: Eric Powell

deck: Filipino writer and artist who worked for Marvel during the 70s.
description:
Virgilio ‚ÄúVirgil‚Äù Redondo y Puruganan was a comic book writer, artist and novelist. He was the eldest of eight children, including his brother Nestor Redondo a fellow comic book artist.

He started as a staff and advertising artist. He published his komik serial Mahiwagang Bundok in 1948.

Virgilio Redondo also worked for Marvel Comics on such titles as Planet of the Apes, Unknown Worlds of Science Fiction, Savage Sword of Conan, The Tomb of Dracula, Tales of the Zombie and Vampire Tales.
name: Virgilio Redondo

name: Sonny Trinidad

deck: Artist and co-creator responsible for the Green Lantern who started working in comics in the 40s, later moving into advertising where he created the Pillsbury Dough-boy.
description:
According to Mr. Nodell In 1940 he was taking a Subway ride in Manhattan to his Brooklyn home when he saw a trainman waving a lantern along the dark track. This coupled with an imaginary ring inspired the character of Green Lantern (Alan Scott). Martin Nodell who commonly signed his name "Mart Nodell" co created the first Green Lantern alongside writer Bill Finger (co-creator of Batman,Robin, Joker etc). When Mart Nodell started out under a pseudonym because at the time he felt comics were a "forbidden literature" and it was "culturally unacceptable." Nodell also worked for Timely Comics (which would one day become Marvel). Under which he drew Captain America, The Sub-Mariner and The Human Torch.

When the Green Lantern first appeared Martin "Mart" Nodell actually recorded his name as Mart Dellon (a rearranging of the spelling of his actual last name)

Characters Created by Mart Nodell

  • Pillsbury Doughboy
  • Alan Scott
  • Doiby Dickles
  • Vandal Savage
  • Wind Master
  • Wooden Man
  • Yalan Gur
  • Gambler
  • Irene Miller
name: Martin Nodell

deck: Mexican artist and colourist
description:
Career

David Curiel first got involved in the comics industry in 2005 when he was one of the colourists for the first issue of Alias Enterprises'¬†Lullaby: Wisdom Seeker. He continued working as a colourist throughout the 2000s, starting out mainly with Alias and Dynamite Entertainment. He has also provided colour work for Marvel, DC and Top Cow, among others. For DC he provided cover art for an issue of Justice League of America, and recently did letters for DC Comics Presents: Legion of Super-Heroes.¬†

Personal Life

Curiel currently lives in Gudalajara, Mexico.
name: David Curiel

He has also worked as a character developer, concept design and storyboard artist in the gaming industry.

deck: Douglass Rushkoff is an academic, theorist, lecturer, writer and columnist. His work in comic books includes the series Testament at DC/Vertigo.
description: Douglas Rushkoff is co-creator, along with Liam Sharp, of Vertigo's Testament. This series is marked by its triple narrative‚Äîone recounting various narratives from the Hebrew Scriptures, or the Old Testament, another creating loosely parallel narratives in a not too distant dystopian future, and a third narrative set in a spiritual plane where the gods do battle by manipulating humanity for their own ends.
name: Douglas Rushkoff

deck: Former editor and writer for Vertigo comics.
description:
Jonathan Vankin gave up a career in journalism to write comics for Vertigo.¬† Find more of a passion to behind the scenes, Jonathan Vankin became an editor for Vertigo.¬† A very brave and bold editor who was willing to try new things, such as more Original Graphic Novels and also bring Harvey Pekar over to Vertigo.
¬†
With many of his titles suffering financially and the death of Harvey Pekar, it became obvious that there was little room for him in the restructuring of DC Comics.¬† It was announce in late September of 2010 that Jonathan Vankin alongside rising star editor Pornsak Pichetshote would be laid off from Vertigo.¬† With the company focusing on finance figures, many of the current Vertigo titles had to be reevaluated.¬†¬†

Vankin is set to restart his comics writing career again starting in the DCU, his first assignment is to write the mini-series Brightest Day aftermath: The search for Swamp Thing.
¬†
name: Jonathan Vankin

deck: Chris Biggs is a writer, who has worked on various Marvel Handbooks.
description:
Brief History

The youngest of four children, Biggs spent her elementary and high school years drawing pictures on the backs of various handouts and homework papers. At age 13 a relative took her to a comic book/Sci-Fi store, where a copy of Marvel's Star Wars series (#64) stared at her from the racks, convincing the Star Wars fan to buy her first comic ever. This led the impressionable teen to begin a lifelong addiction to impossibly powered people in tights, and a strong desire to one day write and draw her own stories of same. When appendix website owner Jeff Christiansen asked for extra writing help for the Fantastic Four Encyclopedia, Biggs happily joined him in fulfilling her lifelong dream of professionally writing for Marvel. Currently Biggs is involved in getting her writing and drawing skills back up to speed, attempting to get freelance photography jobs in an impossibly tight market, and writing profiles on various Marvel characters while working as a wageslave cashier at Job McHell.
name: Chris Biggs

deck: Rich Green is a writer, who has worked on various Marvel Handbooks.
name: Rich Green

deck: Madison Carter is a writer, who has worked on various Marvel Handbooks.
name: Madison Carter

deck: Al Sjoerdsma is a writer, who has worked on various Marvel Handbooks.
description: Al's lifelong love of comics began in the 1960's when, as a kid, he discovered the Stan Lee/ Jack Kirby Fantastic Four, the Stan Lee/Jack Kirby Thor, and especially the Stan Lee/ Steve Ditko Spider-Man. Thinking he had outgrown the medium, Al quit reading for a number of years during which time Gwen Stacy was killed, convincing Al that things could not be trusted to go smoothly without him. He joined Jonathan Couper's Spiderfan.org in its first year and has written for it ever since, his current project being a near panel-by-panel examination of all Spider-Man appearances from the very beginning. After assisting with the Spider-Man Encyclopedia and Spider-Man: 500 Covers, Al became the Head Writer/Coordinator for the Spider-Man 2005 Handbook and continues to write for the Handbooks. He has written over 80 plays and had productions in New York, Miami, Cleveland, Milwaukee, Albuquerque and elsewhere. He even has some plays published but they are hard to find.
name: Al Sjoerdsma

deck: American artist and writer best known for his comic Johnny the Homicidal Maniac and television series Invader ZIM
description:
Career

Jhonen Vasquez began creating his own comics very early in life. The earliest version of his most famous character, Johnny C, was first published by his high school newspaper. In 1992 he graduated from high school and began attending college with a major in film studies. By 1993 he had dropped out of college and taken up professional cartooning. During this time,¬†Carpe Noctem magazine began to publish one-page instalments of early Johnny comics. He began to send examples of his work to Slave Labor Graphics, which lead in 1995 to the release of the first issue of his comic, Johnny the Homicidal Maniac. Johnny continued to be published for the next two years, during which he accumulated a dedicated cult following, and by 1996 he was able to dedicate himself full-time to artistic pursuits. That same year he released The Bad Art Collection, a short collection of art originally produced in high school in response to constant demands from classmates for art. Johnny concluded publication in 1997, and Vasquez began work on a four-issue spin-off based on a character from Johnny, his tiny neighbour Todd Casil, also known as Squee!. This was followed in 1999 by a two-issue comic, I Feel Sick, again centred around a supporting character introduced in Johnny, Devi D, with whom Johnny had a disastrous date in the second issue. In 2001 he released the first of three Fillerbunny comics, the last of which was released in 2005. Also in 2001 he created the animated children's television series Invader Zim, for which he was head writer and original character designer, as well as providing the voices for a number of secondary and background characters. The series was cancelled after two seasons due to low ratings and disinterest from the network, Nickelodeon, with the final episode airing in early December 2002. Despite this brevity it has maintained a large cult following. In 2002 he wrote the one-shot Everything Can Be Beaten, with art by Crab Scrambly. In 2006 he directed the video to Mindless Self Indulgence's song "Shut Me Up", providing artwork for their deluxe album if two years later. In 2007 he wrote the comic Jellyfist with Jenny Goldberg providing the illustrations; it did not perform very well, and plans for a similar comic were abandoned. In 2009 he provided a story about MODOK for Marvel's Strange Tales, and the following year provided a story about Wolverine for Strange Tales II. In 2010 he provided artwork for MC Frontalot's album Zero Day. Also in 2010 he directed the video for The Left Rights' song "White." ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬†

Personal Life

Jhonen Vasquez was born and raised in San Jose, California. He suffers from hypnophobia. He has received an International Horror Guild Award for his work, as well as being nominated for two Eisner Awards. Invader Zim has also won an Emmy and an Annie, as well as being nominated for seven other awards. He occasionally uses the pseudonym "Chancre Scolex" or, simply, "Mr Scolex," both of which are based on a character that he intended to introduce into the Johnny series but was unable to.¬†
name: Jhonen Vasquez

deck: J.T. Krul is a writer who got his big start at Aspen MLT with Fathom and Soulfire. He is now among DC's stable of writers, writing Green Arrow and Teen Titans.
description:
Career

Aspen

Formerly a production assistant and eventually production coordinator on the television series Seinfeld, J.T. Krul started a career as a comic writer in 2004 and found a home at Aspen MLT. He became a prominent writer for the company, writing numerous Fathom and Soulfire series. Krul wrote so many issues of each that he became the major writer for both mythologies.

DC Comics

While writing for Aspen MLT, Krul slowly became more and more known at DC Comics. He worked his way in writing short one or two issue stories for JSA Classified, Titans and Joker's Asylum: Poison Ivy. This soon led to him writing the Blackest Night: Titans tie-in limited series for DC's Blackest Night event.

In his first major work for DC, he was given the reins of the Green Arrow franchise and wrote the Rise of Arsenal and Fall of Green Arrow story arc that explored the consequences of Roy Harper's mutilation and Lian Harper's death in Justice League: Cry for Justice. It was a story direction that was widely criticized and unpopular before he even began. Justice League: the Rise of Arsenal, which featured Roy falling back into his drug addiction, quickly became the target of ridicule and outrage for the very dramatized depiction of Roy's intoxicated state and the graphic nature of how it recounted Lian's death. Despite this, Krul went on to be the regular writer the Brightest Day relaunch of Green Arrow.

Krul also became the new regular writer of Teen Titans around this time, teaming with Nicola Scott to stabilize a book that had struggled to find its solid footing after Geoff Johns' departure years earlier.

A little over a year after taking over Green Arrow and Teen Titans, DC's Flashpoint event brought about a mass relaunch of all of DC's titles, bringing an end to the runs that came before. However, it was announced that Krul would not be done with Green Arrow and would be the writer on the relaunched Green Arrow series. Along with that, he was named the writer of ,.a new Captain Atom series.

In October 2011 he revealed he would by leaving Green Arrow after issue 3 and was replaced by Dan Jurgens & Keith Giffen but he said he would continue to work on Captain Atom.

Some Created Characters

DC

  • Dr. Caligan
  • Galahad
  • Headcase
  • Doll Face

name: J.T. Krul

deck: Golden Age artist who worked for Timely Comics which later became Marvel during the 40s and 50's.
description:
Allen Bellman was born in Manhattan in 1924. He studied at the High School for Industrial Arts.

In the Early 40's he became a staff artist for Timely Comics. He did work for Captain America, The Human Torch, The Patriot, The Destroyer, Jap Buster Johnson, Jet Dixon of the Space Squadron, All Winners Comics, Marvel Mystery Comics, Sub Mariner Comics, Young Allies, Vampire Brats, Suspense and many more.

He is a reknowned photographer and is one of the few remaining pioneers of the comic industry.

Terrific with fans, very nice and loves to tell stories!!!!
name: Al Bellman

deck: Javier Grillo-Marxuach is a writer that has worked for Marvel Comics. He is writing the upcoming Annihilation Conquest-Wraith limited series and has worked on the Lost and Medium television shows.
name: Javier Grillo-Marxuach

deck: Electric Crayon was a digital coloring company started by Steve Buccellato, Marc Siry and Douglas Rosen in 1992. It went out of business in 1994.
description:
Electric Crayon was a digital coloring company started by Steve Buccellato, Marc Siry and Douglas Rosen in Los Angeles in 1992. It shared the same space as Richard Starking's new comic Comicraft at the same time. Unfortunately, Electric Crayon went out of business in 1994 when Buccellato and Siry went on to create a content company called Mad Science Media.
¬†
Electric Crayon held contracts with a number of comic companies during its run, including DC, Marvel, Bongo, and Penthouse.
name: Electric Crayon

deck: Colorist.
name: Beth Sotelo

deck: Writer, Actor and Producer. Worked on the complete run of the Post-Civil War New Warriors.
description:
Career

Writer in charge of restarting the New Warriors comic after the last New Warriors team's actions led to the destruction of Stamford Ct. and led to the Civil War. The 2007 run of New Warriors also addressed the aftermath of House of M and Decimation, by creating the team out of depowered mutants such as Jubilee (Wondra), Beak (Black Wing) Angel (Tempest). Also creator of Blue Marvel and writer of Blue Marvels first mini series Adam: Legend Of The Blue Marvel.

He is also an actor and screenwriter. His most prominent role is that of the character Raze in the Underworld films.
name: Kevin Grevioux

deck: A German comic book artist.
description: Nic Klein was the artist of the five-issue miniseries by Image called Dancer. He also worked on Winter Soldier series written by Jason LaTour until its cancellation with issue #19.
name: Nic Klein

deck:
Marvel Comics: Production Artist and Graphic Designer
2006-2007
description: Worked in the Marvel Bullpen designing, laying out and doing pre-press production on interiors, recap pages, letters pages and all the covers for the X-men Office and Marvel Adventures Office.
name: Kate Levin

deck: Artist.
name: St√©phane Roux

deck: Italian penciller currently drawing All-New X-Factor. He has worked in acclaimed Marvel Knights miniseries such as Daredevil; Battlin' Jack Murdock and X-Men; Magneto Testament. He has also worked doing film storyboards for directors such as Martin Scorcese.
name: Carmine Di Giandomenico

deck: J.K. Woodward is a cover and content artist for IDW's "Fallen Angel".
description:
J.K. Woodward started illustrating comics in 2003 and has worked on many titles including CSI NY, G.I. Joe Cobra, Star Trek Next Generation, BOOM! Studios Eureka, POE and Zombie Tales. When Peter David was re-launching his creator owned series Fallen Angel at IDW, J.K. was a natural choice for Peter's dark world of magic, violence and redemption.

In 2008 his painted work caught the attention of Marvel who chose him to illustrate X-men Origins: The Beast, but his most recent work on Star Trek/Doctor Who: Assimilation brought his art to the masses.
name: J. K. Woodward

deck: Golden Age artist who worked for Marvel/Timely, DC, and David McKay among others.
name: Jimmy Thompson

deck: Letterer for the IDW volume of "Fallen Angel"
name: Robbie Robbins

deck: Editor of IDW volume "Fallen Angel"
name: Chris Ryall

deck: Stand-out  early Golden Age artist, creator of Wesley Dodds aka The Sandman, Scorchy Smith, and the autobiographical Three Aces. Volunteered as a fighter pilot & fought the Japanese as a member of the famous Flying Tigers; killed in action over Rangoon, Burma .
name: Bert Christman

deck: A four-woman manga creation team!
description:
The members of CLAMP are:

Mokona Apapa

The main artist for most of the series, the character, Mokona, is named after her.

Nanase Okawa

The script writer who sometimes writes screenplays for the animated versions of the manga.

Satsuki Igarashi

A general art assistant who also designs the tankobons (which are the volumes with multiple chapters in them, similar to a trade paperback)

They've had many series produced including: [[X/1999: char:18506]]
name: CLAMP

deck: Paul Tobin is comic book writer whose best known works include: Colder, Bandette, Mystery Girl, Plants vs. Zombies, The Witcher, Angry Birds Comics, Prometheus: Fire & Stone, The Age of the Sentry, Marvel Adventures: Fantastic Four, Marvel Adventures: Super Heroes, Marvel Adventures: Spider-Man, and other titles. He is the author of the Genius Factor series of middle-grade novels, and Prepare To Die!, a super-hero themed contemporary fantasy novel.
description:
Paul Tobin is a fairly young up and coming comic book writer who started with the all ages mini-series Banana Sunday (under the¬†¬†pseudonym¬†Paul Nobit) from Oni Press. The 4-issue series, about a young girl attending a new school while caring for 3 talking monkeys, was illustrated by Tobin's wife, Colleen Coover.¬†
¬†¬†
Tobin¬†later began writing for Marvel with the all-ages imprint, Marvel Adventures. His first title in that imprint was the Fantastic Four, but he would also write the Avengers, Super Heroes, and most prominently Spider-Man.¬†¬†Some of his latest work has included the King Size Spider-Man Summer Special which he again collaborated on with his wife, Colleen.
name: Paul Tobin

deck: Artist.  He has recently worked on Spider-Man Family.
name: Pierre Alary

deck: Colorist.  Recently worked on Spider-Man Family.
name: Jean Paul Fernandez

deck: A New York Times best-selling author of works such as Cowboys & Aliens, Marvel Zombies 3, Incredible Hercules and Archer & Armstrong.
description:
Current Work

Fred Van Lente launched the current Archer & Armstrong series for Valiant Entertainment and is writing a number of Brain Boy mini-series' for Dark Horse Comics.

Previous Work

Van Lente is the co-creator, along with artist Ryan Dunlavey, of Evil Twin Comics, which published Action Philosophers. His Marvel work includes co-authoring Incredible Hercules with Greg Pak, as well as writing Marvel Zombies 3, Marvel Zombies 4 and two one-shots as part of Marvel Zombies Return. Van Lente has also written the first issue of Deadpool Team-Up and the Dark Reign mini series All-New Savage She-Hulk.

Van Lente created a new Power Man, Victor Alvarez, who first appeared in the Shadowland: Power Man mini-series, followed by a new Power Man and Iron Fist series, also by Van Lente. He has also written a number of issues of The Amazing Spider-Man.

Other Media

Van Lente's book Cowboys & Aliens was turned into a big budget movie of the same name, starring Harrison Ford and Daniel Craig. He is also the co-author, alongside Greg Pak, of the book Make Comics Like The Pros.
name: Fred Van Lente

deck: Colorist.
name: Michelle Madsen
